This improvement to the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children program is *especially* needed now as many schools across the country remain closed and children have a harder time obtaining free school meals.

Essential workers have made immense sacrifices to be here when our country needs them most, and it is now up to Congress to ensure that we will be there for them should they fall ill.

No essential worker should have to struggle to pay rent, keep their lights on, or put food on the table if they become sick while providing these services. 

We need bold action to show every essential worker that we will not leave them behind.

The fund would help essential workers with medical costs, loss of employment, loss of business, replacement services, and burial costs. Importantly, family members who get sick due to their contact with essential workers would also be eligible.

The bipartisan Pandemic Heroes Compensation Act, modeled after the 9/11 Victim Compensation Fund, would provide critical financial assistance for essential workers, across all industries, and their families if they become sick or die due to #COVID19.

These essential workers have left the safety of their homes to put their lives on the line for the country, often without adequate protection. Despite the immense risk, they answered the call to service during the #COVID19 pandemic, and many have paid with their lives.

The first responders, transit workers, grocery store clerks, delivery workers, janitorial staff, mail carriers, hospitality workers, and federal, state and local employees who are on the frontlines are risking their health to make sure we are safe, fed, and healthy.

On September 11th, it was the firefighters and officers who ran into the burning buildings to save lives. Today, it is hospital workers ‚Äì nurses, doctors, EMS, janitorial staff, pharmacists, technicians and all essential workers. 

We owe them more than applause at 7pm.

We have a moral responsibility to help essential workers who are risking their health every single day during this crisis. 

That's why, I have introduced the Pandemic Heroes Act to establish a compensation fund for essential workers who become ill or die as a result of #COVID19 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EX_7hC7WsAYiAi1.jpg

I urge House leadership to put aside any desire to use this as a political opportunity and instead focus on getting results in a bipartisan, bicameral way. The American people need our help. We must deliver in a way that's responsive and a responsible use of taxpayer dollars.

I worked with colleagues across the aisle to secure help for small business, critical funding for state and local governments, support for Tribal communities, and lower insurance costs. But unfortunately, the HEROES Act contains many measures unrelated to direct COVID-19 relief.

I know we can find common ground to address the health and economic crisis facing our country. We achieved strong bipartisan support in the last three relief bills and the HEROES Act contains many bipartisan provisions that I fought for.
We must work with our Republican colleagues and leadership in the Senate to negotiate a targeted relief bill that is aimed squarely at the health and economic challenges we face.

She'll only be able to continue her essential work as a nurse if she can renew her DACA status.
Lu now works at a hospital in Denver, and is about to complete her second degree in Nursing. Her goal is to become an emergency room nurse and a teacher to future nurses.

She focused on her education and graduated with a degree in Molecular Biology and Genetics. After being granted DACA status, Lu was able to pursue opportunities in the health care field, and after working as an EMT for years, she fell in love with caring for others.

In search of better work and educational opportunities, Lu‚Äôs parents brought her to the U.S. when she was 13. After years of trying to obtain legal residency, she and her family became undocumented.
As we think about the Americans whose lives could be upended by the looming #DACA SCOTUS decision, Lu‚Äôs story is one of countless stories to share.
